Job Summary:
The level of complexity and the speed of change within the Finance Division has increased and will continue to do so as the Finance Division continues to evolve to support the various functions across the organization. As a result, there is a need for experienced senior risk professionals to provide the necessary leadership and oversight to support the Finance Division and the organization.

What you will do:
Lead the design, implementation and maintenance of the Internal Control over Financial Reporting (ICFR) program across HOOPP.
As the expert in National Instrument 52-109, SOX 404 and the COSO framework, ensure that the ICFR program adheres to all applicable regulations and standards.
Lead the development strategy, setting policies and guidelines and ensure that industry best practices have been adopted.
As the knowledge expert on best practices for controls, conduct research and share ‘best practice’ principles to ensure consistent standards and practices are applied across HOOPP.
Foster an enhanced compliance and risk culture by acting as an ambassador for the ICFR program.
Develop and maintain relationships with key stakeholders across the organization and act as an expert on financial reporting controls.
Identify areas of dependencies and risks amongst the various Divisions (Finance, Plan Operations and IT) and provide advice and develop plans to mitigate the risk to HOOPP.
Collaborate with all HOOPP Divisions to develop and maintain an in-depth understanding of key business and IT processes in order to identify key financial reporting risks and mitigating controls.
Leverage controls and risk expertise, along with business knowledge, to provide support to the Finance Division by identifying potential areas of vulnerability and risk and work with the process owners to develop corrective action plans.
Participate in Finance initiatives as the lead in the design of internal controls over financial reporting to mitigate risks.
Lead the review and evaluation of controls for system implementations.
Lead the oversight and evaluation of SOC reports.
Lead a team in the identification, assessment and documentation of internal controls, risks and gaps and make recommendations as required.
Establish documentation standards and provide leadership to the creation and maintenance of detailed internal controls documentation.
Lead the continued enhancement of practices, strategy, and methodologies from a compliance testing and validation perspective.
Lead the development and execution of test plans and work collaboratively with both the internal and external auditors, as applicable. Manage and maintain these relationships and resolve issues in a timely manner.
Negotiate and manage remediation plans for internal control gaps and / or weaknesses identified during testing.
Work with the VP, Finance Governance & Tax to prepare periodic reports to Senior Management (including the CFO and CEO) and quarterly reports to the Audit & Finance Committee on the effectiveness of ICFR.
Develop and facilitate education sessions to allow stakeholders to develop an understanding of the design and implementation of internal controls for their area.
Lead change through effective communication and meaningful coaching, both within and outside of Finance, as applicable, that will support the organization’s long-term needs and goals and position the ICFR team as a valued asset.
Manage a team of Risk and Controls professionals and ensure that they possess the necessary skills, knowledge and competencies to perform their function.
Stay abreast of industry current innovations and best practices and apply them for HOOPP.
Represent HOOPP at peer group meetings.

Department: Corporate Services

Language: Bilingual; English and French


Background:


The Federation of Canadian Municipalities (FCM) is the national voice of municipal governments, representing the interests of cities and communities with the federal government. FCM’s Strategic Plan calls upon FCM to work collaboratively to: a) expand national understanding and support of the role local governments play in meeting national objectives; b) shape the national agenda by influencing decision-makers and opinion-leaders to ensure that the interests of municipalities are met or exceeded; c) build capacity and knowledge, thereby encouraging initiative and innovation, which in turn helps local governments rise to the challenges they face; and d) share its knowledge and experience on the world’s stage, so that others may improve the quality of life in their communities.

Major Purpose:

Reporting to the Senior Manager, Risk Management unit (RMU) the Risk Management Analyst will contribute to ensuring appropriate risk management is exercised in order to help maintain the long-term sustainability and financial soundness of the Green Municipal Fund (GMF).


Key Responsibilities:

Deal Activity

Reviews applications, contracts, and deal leads for risk issues relating to transactions at all stages of the loan transaction process including pricing, initial risk assessments, structuring issues, and engages the Senior Analyst/Senior Manager, RMU as needed for more complex and/or strategic issues.
Reviews and provides critical analysis of deal submissions prior to passing them onto the Senior Analyst, Risk Management Unit. For Stream I projects, evaluates and confirms if the proposed credit rating is acceptable.
Provides support to the Senior Analyst for Stream II & Stream III projects in reviewing the proposed credit ratings. This includes; validating cash flow model assumptions, stress testing models, security valuation and analyzing financial statements/business plans.
Compiles information for appendices that are required for deal submissions to the Risk Committee and Council including: (i) extent of filling of ASPO risk buckets for the current fiscal year; (ii) extent that portfolio fills risk buckets overall; (iii) pipeline per risk bucket if available; (iv) Mix of 10/20 year maturities for the year; and (v) others as determined by current procedures.

Monitors and updates pricing information from Municipal Finance Authorities/Corporations. Closely monitors and documents comparable interest rates provided by Municipal Finance Authorities/Corporations. Supports the Senior Manager-Investments on an - as required basis
Performs risk assessment for non-municipal grant applicants for GMF program.


Portfolio Monitoring and Reporting

Monitors portfolio and transaction exposures against risk limits according to parameters set out in relevant RMU procedures/policies & using judgment depending on lending organization.
Reviews all counterparties to GMF loan agreements with outstanding balances for changes in credit quality, at a frequency determined by its internal rating, as per RMU policies/procedures. If there is a change in credit risk rating, provides recommendation and support material to the Senior Analyst/RMU Head for reclassification.
Prepares portfolio reports, approved by RMU Head, on frequency determined by relevant procedures/policies, including Annual Report, Quarterly Reports and Council Reports.
Continually monitors and updates the loan portfolio for any changes in credit risk composition. Creates reports showing the changes in risk composition of the loan portfolio.
Contributes to the development of appropriate risk targets and policies for individual transactions, and portfolio concentrations. Helps to monitor how much of each “bucket” of risk has been filled to provide timely management information.
Responsible for post-commitment monitoring of loans once hand-off has occurred from Contracts, including monitoring for covenant compliance and other conditions in the loan documentation, and advises RMU Head and GMF Project Officers and Finance staff of any issues, anomalies or risks.
Analyzes and recommends GMF’s response for any waiver, amendment or consent requests made by a Borrower.


Secretary of the Risk Committee (RC)

Coordinates with RC chair and members to convene RC meetings as required; prepares RC Agenda in consultation with RC chair and RMU Head and circulates to RC members.
Coordinates with Funding Services and others regarding information required to circulate to RC members (on deals or other matters).
Prepares and circulates minutes recording discussions held and decisions taken in regard to loan deals and maintains minutes log.

University degree in a business administration or finance related discipline.
Experience in risk management with an emphasis on municipal, project risk. Knowledge of corporate lending an asset
Capital markets knowledge is a definite asset.
Private sector financial institutional experience is an asset.
Requires strong analytical skills
Ability to work effectively with all levels of internal and external stakeholders, excellent client service and communication skills.
Advanced knowledge of Microsoft Office, specifically Excel and databases (CRM).
Demonstrated ability to prioritize and meet regular deadlines.
Highly organized and the ability to work unsupervised
High level of accuracy and attention to detail is essential

The Manager, Finance and Data Analysis plays a key role in assisting with the management of the Faculty's finances and data. Accountable for supporting the implementation of the new FSRA Pensions engagement strategy with pension plan administrators and ensuring that plans are well governed, risk mitigation strategies are in place, and rights of plan beneficiaries are protected

Works with the Director and colleagues to develop, implement and communicate new concepts, approaches and best practices to drive the relationship management strategy as part of the development and implementation of measured, graduated and proportionate action plans, on-site examinations and regulatory responses in a risk-based manner for plans at risk and distressed plans.

Provides technical expertise, advice and recommendations related to the development, implementation and evaluation of pension legislation, pension policies and guidelines for the regulation of pension plans registered with FSRA.
Provides technical expertise, advice and recommendations related to PBGF eligibility, financial status, claims management, oversight of investment managers and appointed administrators, accounting, risk management, and reporting.
Prepares reports of results, challenges, and recommendations as part of ongoing feedback loop.

Education and Experience
Degree in business, finance, actuarial science, accounting, auditing, mathematics, or a related field or a professional designation.

Building a best-in-class risk analytics infrastructure.

Liaises with Operating Unit Managers (OUMs) and other internal stakeholders on budget, cost issues, and Institute budgetary policies and procedures; responds to requests, problem solves, and prepares a variety of financial reports.
Performs ongoing analysis of salary accounts and operating budgets and performs budget transfers as needed.
Maintains position control number (PCN) system; reviews and approves requests for PCNs and ensures correct coding, approval and budget allocation.
Assists in testing changes to the financial database, including analysis of data integrity.
Reviews, approves and processes departmental budget change requests.
Supports the budget process: Assists OUMs with budget preparation and analysis, evaluates OUM submissions, reviews revenue, salary, and non-salary change requests to ensure reasonableness.
Compiles monthly consolidated forecast data for the operating and restricted funds, analyzes, summarizes and reports significant variances to the Manager, Payroll, Budgets and Analysis.
Assists in the coordination of the forecasting process by communicating timelines, requirements and technical updates.
Liaises with Information Technology Services (ITS) and the TM1 project team to ensure online systems and reports meet the needs of the internal stakeholders.
Develops and delivers training for managers and groups on campus to promote understanding of the budgeting and forecasting process.
Processes quarterly budget and forecast review by preparing analysis for review based on actuals, budgets and projections prepared by the OUMs.
Reviews budget-related and position control functions and recommends procedural and policy changes as deemed necessary.
Reviews, with the OUMs, anomalies in monthly revenues and expenditures (for all funds) and obtains explanations, and discusses possible solutions and preventative measures
Verifies availability of funds, compliance with spending guidelines, and appropriate signatory for financial transactions.
Trains new systems users and provides ongoing technical support to internal clients on the reporting systems.
Reviews, processes, and maintains month-end restricted funds transactions and discusses possible resolutions and preventative measures.
Reconciles operating budget and prepares budget upload financial information.
Reviews requests for the creation of restricted funds; ensures documentation and recommendations are in place.
Assists OUMs with annual budget development by providing guidance on completing the variance analysis and updating TM1 with corresponding budget adjustments/allocations.
Participates on internal and working committees related to budget and records and compiles budget information as required.
Assists in preparing the consolidated annual budget and quarterly forecast via reconciliation of budget and forecast submissions received from the OUMs.
Assists in preparing and creating payroll reports to aid management and provides ad-hoc reporting as required. • Assists with maintaining and reconciling payroll data elements to the budget to ensure consistency of application and calculation.
Reviews requests for salary budget transfers and creation of new PCNs; ensures adequate payroll documentation is established.
Ensures approved initiatives and annual budget are properly recorded and reconciled in TM1 and Banner.
Initiates discussions on budget, forecast, position control or restricted fund problems/concerns with the Manager, Payroll, Budgets and Analysis.
Acts on behalf of the Manager, Payroll, Budgets and Analysis during absences as appropriate.


Qualifications

Completion of the Chartered Professional Accounting (CPA) program.
Three to five years’ experience in a similar position that includes analytical analysis, financial statement reporting, budget development, forecasting, and capital fund accounting.

JOB PURPOSE:
The Financial Policy Advisor provides policy support, research and advice to the Finance and Facilities Management division, Senior Management Executive, Committees and Convocation. This includes research and benchmarking of best practices within relevant external organizations, provision of advice and recommendations with respect to financial policies, and identification and analysis of issues with potential impact upon the Law Society in the short, medium and long-term. The Financial Policy Advisor directs the preparation of the agenda for the Audit and Finance Committee including the development and monitoring of its work plan and performs similar for any Working Groups or Task Forces of the Committee. The Financial Policy Advisor collaborates with the Finance directors and the Policy Division to ensure appropriate costing and financial benchmarks are included in policy initiatives requiring the use of Law Society financial, physical and/or human resources. The Financial Policy Advisor will facilitate and guide the implementation of an Enterprise Risk Management framework across the Law Society and the subsequent monitoring and updating of the framework. The position manages for the Law Society, Law Society Foundation (LSF) and LiRN Inc. (LiRN), the assessment and acquiring of relevant insurance, including but not limited to officers and directors, liability, property and cyber risk coverage. Working with the Office of General Counsel, the Financial Policy Advisor will develop and implement a compliance reporting framework that apprises the Audit and Finance Committee of the Law Society’s status on statutory requirements, contractual obligations as well as compliance with policies of Convocation. The Financial Policy Advisor works closely with the Senior Leadership Team in Finance to provide guidance with respect to financial statement presentation ensuring compliance with current accounting principles and standards as well as assessing and implementing upcoming changes impacting the Law Society. The position is accountable for liaising with and overseeing efforts of service providers and experts such as investment consultants and actuaries related to the evaluation of investment manager(s) and Compensation Fund reserves. The Financial Policy Advisor provides similar support and services to the boards and officers of LSF and LiRN.

A university degree and completion of a recognized accounting designation (CPA) or equivalent.
A minimum of 10 years previous related experience providing senior level financial and/or policy analysis and recommendations, preferably in a not‑for‑profit or public service environment.
Solid grounding in management and general accounting policies, procedures and functions.
Solid grounding in research, analytical and statistical theory and methodology in support of policy development and committee / governing body decision-making processes.
Solid grounding in financial software applications and spreadsheet analysis, particularly the use of database applications, queries and custom report generation.
Thorough understanding of the impact of technology on the finance and accounting function, particularly with respect to analysis and presentation of financial information.
Thorough understanding of risk management, assessment and compliance.
Expressive and persuasive in both spoken and written language for individual and / or group situations (committees, management, senior management).
Interprets, applies and presents complex information in an audience appropriate manner.
Sound judgment, tact and sensitivity to function as non-partisan staff in a "government" setting.
Proven ability to work under pressure.
Proven ability to assess challenges from multiple and different perspectives, to think big and differently and to craft creative solutions.

The Second LOD consists of 'Risk Stewards' who are independent of the commercial risk-taking activities undertaken by the First LOD. The Compliance function is a Risk Steward for a number of non-financial risks in accordance with HSBC Group’s risk framework.

The Diversity VC Standard is an assessment and certification program that measures the DEI programming at venture capital firms and benchmarks their performance against an evidence-based global standard. The program is a joint effort by Diversio and Diversity VC, and was developed with the aim of encouraging the adoption of policies and programs that will lead to a more diverse, equitable, and inclusive venture capital industry. To this end, the Standard also provides VCs with the tools, resources, and understanding needed to diversify their talent networks and provide funding to underrepresented founders. The program was launched in September of 2020 by 15 leading venture capital funds across Europe and Canada, and has since expanded globally, with over 60 of the leading venture capital funds globally. You can read more about the Diversity VC Standard here.

Collaborating with key stakeholders to plan, organize, and execute learning & connection events for member funds
Jointly facilitating Diversity VC Standard Advisory Board discussions on a quarterly basis
Working with the Diversity VC Standard Advisory Board, as well as Diversity VC and Diversio leadership, to determine the strategic direction of the Standard
Jointly owning program communications to member funds (i.e. monthly newsletter, communications about engagement opportunities) with Diversity VC
Launching new initiatives to generate value and maximize impact for members of our VC community
Working hand-in-hand with the product and platform teams at Diversio to continue to build the Diversity VC Standard dashboard
Developing and executing outreach campaigns to help grow the Standard

REQUIRED SKILLS AND QUALIFICATIONS

2+ years professional full time work experience in Venture Capital, Financial Services, or Consulting
1+ year experience leading Diversity, Equity and Inclusion efforts in a business context
Demonstrated program management work experience
Demonstrated experience leading meetings or consulting senior business executives

Proficient data analysis capabilities (Advanced Excel skills)


RECOMMENDED SKILLS AND QUALIFICATIONS

Ambition to have an impact on the future of the Diversity VC Standard, our current members, and the venture capital ecosystem as a whole
Comfortability interacting and communicating with senior investors within the VC community
Ability to work independently, and as a part of a close-knit team that cheers each other on
Goal-oriented and performance-driven, delivering high-quality work


OUR VALUE PROPOSITION TO YOU


A unique opportunity in a key role at a fast-growing technology company that is setting the global standard for a key social imperative

The Credit Specialist is accountable for the ongoing management and administration of the complex credit book within Private Banking working under the direction/guidance of the Director, Credit. The Credit Specialist role manages the credit quality of the high net worth client base found within Private Banking whose credit needs and financial structures are typically more complex. The role is actively engaged supporting Private Banking Advisors grow their credit opportunities while also ensuring appropriate oversight of their existing credit book.
Note : this role is open to multiple locations nationally.

Provide guidance and offer support on new credit requests with Private Banking Advisors. This will include analyzing and understanding client financial information (holding companies / individuals) and assessing its relative strength against the credit request. This will also include confirming and/or recommending an appropriate lending facility and security structure to support for the proposed credit request. For more complex situations this may involve direct communication with the client and/or their professional advisors to ensure an appropriate understanding of their information and what is being requested.
The Credit Specialist role is involved with preparing credit applications (iCap and CLASS CIBC credit platforms), partnering with Wealth Risk Management in negotiating credit terms, helping with and/or creating loan documentation and helping with and/or liaising directly with back-office on security documentation.
Help manage the existing complex credit book with particular focus managing expiries. This will include identifying expiries ahead of time and working with the Private Bankers/Associates to ensure proper monitoring of the credits, appropriate information is attained and ensuring reviews are completed.
Support leadership team in preparation of deal summaries on large credit requests to allow an appropriate early engagement with senior leadership within Private Banking and Wealth Risk Management.
Provide credit structuring guidance and advice to the Private Banking Advisors and local leadership.
Active engagement within the respective Private Banking office ensuring the Private Banking Advisor and Associate audience are well aware of credit policy and procedures within the Private Banking segment.

Manage the monthly execution and analysis of the credit Earnings-at-Risk and Capital-at-Risk processes, which would include:

Support the Model Vetting Unit in their efforts related to vetting and validation of the Earnings-at-Risk and Capital-at-Risk models.
Support Director Credit Risk analytics in annual credit risk audit

Lead the analysis of portfolio management actions that impact credit risk utilization (Earnings-at-Risk, Capital-at-Risk);
Act as a general quantitative resource for senior leaders of the Corporate Risk Office credit risk group;
Leading research efforts as required;

Input files for cEaR/CaR processes;
Contributions to the quarterly Investment Risk Monitoring Report;
Variance analysis of changes in cVaR results;
Ad-hoc reports/presentations to summarize one-off projects;

2 years of experience in quantitative analysis, or credit portfolio management in a global, multi-sector context;

Strong communication, presentation and public-speaking skills

To address this, Ecojustice has developed a strategy to hold corporations and financial institutions accountable for making risky investment and operational decisions inconsistent with a low-carbon future through litigation and by working with governments to develop strong, transparent legislation for climate finance in Canada – and that’s where you come in. The creation of this new role will help us achieve our accountability strategy.
About the Role:
As a Staff Lawyer, Finance & Climate, you will be at the cutting edge of environmental law: working with Ecojustice lawyers from across Canada in bringing strategic, game-changing public interest lawsuits and reforming Canada’s laws to deliver lasting solutions to our most urgent environmental problems.
Working as part of Ecojustice’s program team, you will develop and conduct litigation related to climate finance on behalf of a broad range of clients. Duties also include a range of related tasks that contribute to our organizational effectiveness and are essential to ensuring our legal work has the maximum impact.

Litigation:

As an experienced commercial litigator, you will apply your litigation skills and knowledge of the financial sector to developing and implementing Ecojustice’s climate finance strategy.

Course description: This course introduces a brief overview of essential concepts in accounting and corporate finance for engineering students. The first part of the course covers the fundamentals of accounting. We start by exploring the basic language of accounting and the fundamental concepts of financial reporting. Students learn to read and analyze basic financial statements including the statements of financial position, comprehensive income, changes in equity, and cash flows. Inclusive in this process is answering all credit related inquiries by customers regarding structured approvals and/or release of security (cash or funding delays). Researching credit information for each merchant application via direct phone calls, credit bureaus, merchant’s website and bank references to confirm that merchant is of good credit standing and eliminate potential frauds. Assisting with daily, weekly, monthly and ad-hoc credit & risk reporting.
Participating in identifying and implementing department process improvements.
